Engineering Example 1

Electrostatic potential

Introduction

The electrostatic potential due to a point charge \(Q\) coulombs at a position \(r\) (m) from the charge is given by \[ V = \dfrac{Q}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r} \] where \( \epsilon_0 \), the permittivity of free space, \( \approx 8.85 \times 10^{-12}\  \mathrm{Fm^{-1}}\) and \(\pi \approx 3.14\).

The field strength at position \(r\) is given by \(E =- \dfrac{dV}{dr} \).

Problem in words

Find the electric field strength at a distance of \(5 \ \mathrm{m}\) from a source with a charge of \(1 \ \mathrm{coulomb}\).

Mathematical statement of the problem

\( V = \dfrac{Q}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r} \).

Substitute for \( \epsilon_0\) and \(\pi\) and use \(Q = 1\), so that \[ V = \dfrac{1}{4 \times 3.14 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} r} \approx \dfrac{9 \times 10^9}{r} = 9 \times 10^9 r^{-1}. \] We need to differentiate \(V\) in order to find the electric field strength from the relationship \( E = - \dfrac{dV}{dr} \)

Mathematical analysis

\( E = - \dfrac{dV}{dr} = -9 \times 10^9(-r^{-2}) = 9 \times 10^9 r^{-2} \)

When \(r = 5\). \[ E = \dfrac{9 \times 10^9}{25} = 3.6 \times 10^8 \ \mathrm{Vm}^{-1} \]

Interpretation

The electric field strength is \( 3.6 \times 10^8 \ \mathrm{Vm}^{-1}\) at \(r = 5 \ \mathrm{m}\).

Note that the field potential varies with the reciprocal of distance (i.e. inverse linear law with distance) whereas the field strength obeys an inverse square law with distance.
